job_title: Prior Authorization Specialist in New York, NY
pros: MetroPlus cares about its members, which is apparent in everything we do.
cons: The pharmacy department is a bit small.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The work that MetroPlus does for the community is commendable. I think that the CEO has a good pulse on the needs of their membership and as such, the entire organization is focused on providing a good solution to the customer base. There are quite a number of intelligent people working for the company- Simran Kaur is a gem and as is Ganesh. They are truly great leaders and will always be thankful for the time I worked with them, as I learned a lot.
cons: When I worked there, the environment was a bit chaotic and there was very little strategic direction. We moved from one initiative to another sometimes not fully vetting things but placing too many resources only to change directions. I respect Dr. Schwartz for her accomplishments and she is a very kind person at heart-but I think one area to focus on is the hostility in different areas of the organization. I experienced it a lot there and it came to a point that it was just best to leave- as I don't have that kind of personality and since it is prevalent- no immediate changes were going to take place.

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: Pays well, but health benefits are surprisingly limited despite working for a health insurance company Remote position, but has since started requiring 2 days a week in the office Difficult to be fired, low expectations
cons: Poor communication No bonuses/raises/promotions within 3 years Top-down business practices, management often take ideas from lower staff and pass it off as their own Management has poor attitude/generally low morale Policies constantly change but are not written, everything oral and intentionally confusing Have enforced illegal policies regarding COVID time off and requiring doctors notes for a single day of absence, NYC labor board has intervened for me twice.

job_title: Director of Analytics in New York, NY
pros: Long term stability, some coworkers were really great
cons: Challenging environment evolving from prior CEO to current. Not a lot of staff line employee opinions considered

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Sales is Cool , Benefits are Ok
cons: Even though it's a heath insurance they don't care about their employees health

job_title: Customer Experience Strategy in New York, NY
pros: Excellent project management (PMO) department leadership. Union protection after 1 year of service. Eligible for student loan forgiveness. NYC pension.
cons: Terrible management who bad mouthed other departments (Quality, Project Management, Customer Service) openly to reports. Very political, perception oriented, non-data driven environment. Heavy top-down management with little autonomy to work independently with peers on projects. Perception of effort (personality) rewarded over solid outcomes.

review_title: Growing Company, Good Benefit, Great Opportunity
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: MetroPlus is a health insurance company serving the City of New York. The company is expanding in various markets. That brings a lot of opportunities for career growth. The leadership team has good vision for company's future. All employees are NY City employees. It provides good medical, retirement benefits.
cons: A lot of work. Hiring can't keep up with the work load due to business expansion.

review_title: A great place to thrive in your role with excellent Management

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Good benefits and friendly work environment
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Associate Director, Quality Management in New York, NY
pros: It's Remote, Free health insurance, bunch of Holidays off I suppose. That's basically it
cons: The Micromnagment from a particular manager is overbearing and mentally exhausting. Upper management is aware of the unhealthy work environment this person has caused and refuses to intervene. Department is severely underpaid considers working all LOB's, unlike other health plans that have a team for each LOB. The in-field coordinators are treated with no respect from their manager and other departments. Staff is overworked with insane quotas that have many working off the clock to meet these insane numbers, with no consideration of home life or another work-related task that also needs to be addressed. Many are afraid to speak up due to the fear of retaliation, as many have spoken in the past and were fired shortly after. During the summer about have the team left, due to the high turnover rate, to retain its current employees an adjustment in salary was made, However with all the work and disorganization within the department that new salary is still too low compared to the market. If you are looking for a job working with HEDIS and Quality management, please look elsewhere, you will regret this. There are better companies out there to work for.

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are decent. Option for low health insurance.
cons: Toxic culture. Poor salary. Favoritism. Poor management.

job_title: Pharmacist in Jamaica, NY
pros: Environment, flexible, benefits, schedule, hybrid

review_title: Mission-Driven With a Focus on Community
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Rapidly growing organization with a mission in mind - making sure New Yorkers get amazing health care. People who work here, live in the communities that we service. Everyone that works here care deeply about New York, especially the underserved. Everyone is super nice with a goal in mind - helping the underserved get health care. I've been here for 6 month and love working here.
cons: Lean organization with an all hands on deck mentality. Agile organization that shifts with the market dynamics, so hours and work life can be difficult. But, I guess it's expected since it's a non-profit.

review_title: Process takes time, but we will definitely get there
job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: A lot of the staff are professional from top-down and so far, I have been lucky to collaborate with several teams and learn about their LOB as well as the impact they have towards the rest of the organization. Technology is huge here and the teams are playing with different software. I really like using teams over zoom and the upgraded look for MS 365 just makes things a lot easier to communicate and navigate through. Monday-Friday with some late work sometimes up to and sometimes into 5:45PM. Some people forget this is part of H+HC so this is a NYC position that pays competitively, or if not, more than our competition (HR Generalists, Coordinator, etc.). 401K & NYC Pension is a major game changer if someone is curious about employment in NYC. Other companies mainly provide just a 401K or403B.
cons: Some processes need to be reviewed and thought about when implementing new work.

job_title: Claims in New York, NY
pros: pension plans, city holidays, okay health care.
cons: They need better managment. Lack of training,

job_title: Marketplace Facilitated Enroller in New York, NY
pros: Helpful employees and benefits are great
cons: management could improve and make room for current employee advancement

job_title: ESR I in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
It’s a good job to start out if you just graduated college or have no college degree. Health Insurance Premium is $0, 
Pensión, Union, 
Opportunity for growth, bonus incentive every quarter, you can do OT.
cons:
Last quarter only 15 out of thousands of employees got the bonus…
In order to get the bonus You have to meet you quarterly goal
If you don’t meet your quotas in the first year you are terminated ( if your boss hates you) if your boss doesn’t suck they will set up an action plan.
You have to meet at least 85% of your goal to not get fired.
You have to meet 120% to receive your bonus. 
In order to make the amount of numbers they are asking you gotta push OT everyday.
Once you stop pushing OT it can be a problem, you are left without a work/life balance.
We are forced to work two saturdays a month, sometimes 6 in a row so for a month and a half your killing yourself.
Even if you are unionized you can’t get representation in the first year if you are not meeting Quotas your out.
Most associates last three to six months.
The job is not Sales
It’s like social work
I have sales experience, it’s not sales.
When you sell QHPs at full price thats sales.

job_title: Harp Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good to be working for the City again.
cons: Lots of HR info to go through.

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The onboarding process takes time (about a month including the background check) because the company cares who they hire. They want to ensure that they choose the most qualified candidate who will fit the work culture. MetroPlusHealth is diverse and upbeat. Never a boring day. There is always something to do and many of the employees are tenured, will retire, and expect to receive a pension. You will learn a lot and most if not all are willing to help. There are a lot of health related resources for employees and training if you lack a specific skillset. The company will invest in your long term career.
cons: Work life balance. But it's expected for EAs to work around the clock.

job_title: Training Team Leader in Brooklyn, NY

review_title: I'd give it ZERO stars if I could
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: There is only one pro working for this company - work-life balance
cons: Where to begin... this company is totally dysfunctional. They are so backwards it's like traveling back in time - horrible old unsupported systems resulting in a TON of manual work, incapable IT using ancient technologies, no leadership only finger pointing and nepotism (Dr. Talya Schwartz is the biggest nepotist of them all), insane turnover rate so nothing gets done, good people are underappreciated and underpaid, horrible company work culture - nobody responds to emails, people yell and even curse at each other as a norm, upper management has no idea or interest in what's going on in the company.... trust me, there's more cons, but I hope you get the point.

job_title: Insurance Sales Agent in New York, NY

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: I can’t think of any pros working here. Benefits were mediocre. Pre covid lots of great eateries to dine in.
cons: One of the worst companies in which I've worked in a professional career. This company, particularly the department I was in, operated as a sweatshop. You have incompetent managers running the show. Ridiculous expectations, concentrate solely on quantity rather than quality. There is no guidance at all. Nepotism, narcissistic behavior is the norm. If you’re not in the crowd, then you will be treated like an outcast. I urge you to do your research, ask questions during the interviews and conclude a decision that will not jeopardize your mental health.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Brooklyn, NY

cons: Horrible management, terrible communication skills between departments, and absolutely NO respect for employees.

job_title: Facilitated Enroller in New York, NY
pros: stable pay , remote working

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Great staff who want to do the what is right and what is best for the company.   The benefits are well known and are definitely an advantage.  The culture is definitely trying to change for the better.  That takes time and complete buy in from all levels of management.  In the division I work in (IT) we are working diligently on creating a positive atmosphere by creating repeatable processes, fostering inclusion and growth.
cons:
As in many organizations, there are areas of improvement.  Some of which are realistic and others, based on the fact that we are a city organization, will be difficult to implement.  One of the recurring things that needs to be reviewed is the work from home policy(or lack of one).  With the ever changing landscape of the health care  market, one is the ability and the flexibility to work remotely (at least on occasion)

Many employees stay due to the benefits, but we also need to consider a structure to maintain our assets with a different financial incentive program.

job_title: Sales in New York, NY
pros: Nothing pro about working in this horrible environment
cons: Everything, Supervisors, Director. They make you work in hospitals during pandemic

job_title: Marketing Facilitator in New York, NY
pros: Free healthcare coverage at no pay
cons: supervisors and upper management treat their employees like cattle. They only care about the numbers and have no regard for safety, especially during a pandemic

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The only real pro of the customer service department would be the overtime available. But don't be fooled, it's only if your supervisor likes you.
cons: Where to begin...first off the child like behavior of the management staff is unbelievable. They pick on employees, they look at the littlest thing and will hold it over your head for as long as possible, and the favouritism is just unreal. Most of the management staff is chosen on whos friends with who rather then what they know, because 80% of the supervisors and team leads know NOTHING. Your better off asking your desk neighbor. One supervisor in particular compensates her fear of certain people on her team and picks on the others and jeopardizes their job just to make herself feel better.

review_title: Disgusting and unprofessional environment - stay away.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good for people that want a job, but don't want to work. Union benefits for those who qualify. Good place to refer your worst enemy to work at. If you like to wear skanky, wrinkled clothes, sneakers and jeans everyday, and not comb your hair, this is the place for you.
cons: Bedbug infested, unprofessional, potential waste and abuse of government funded dollars. Poor people and systems management. Disrespectful staff at all levels. Careless customer service. Classic union/socialist environment. Dirty office. Large number of staff members that practice Voodoo and Santeria at their work stations. Poor to no communication. Departments hate each other, staff and management targets good and top performers, the incentive is to work and contribute the minimum so that no one looks bad. This place promotes on the basis of "who you know" not what you know. In my last days there, I found evidence of sabotage by management against good employees. Don't be surprised if you witness employee violence and intimidation.

review_title: Poor Quality of senior level managers for Quality Management Department
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Enjoys NYC benefits which are great.
cons: Ill qualified top management leads to poor objectivity with running the department and hiring down the line. The mentality with senior quality management is "hire someone that will watch my back and be loyal at all costs and as such over and over again hiring ill qualified persons".  The result is a long line of unqualified people and very poor products and remarkable turnover.

review_title: Not for the innovative at heart
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Good benifits
No micro management
Very accomadating with time off
If you are new to the industry this is a good place to do self study and learn it at your own pace. The workload usually doesnt  interfere.
cons:
Cultural mindset of the city organization (once you're in, you're safe)
Lack of communication across departments
Improper utilization of talent
Lack of motivation in workers
Lack of accountability in employees
Help desk is a joke
You will wait FOREVER for access to individual programs or technologies

job_title: in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The health benefits are good
cons: If you're Black American or Dominican you've found the right place. The employees are so unprofessional, the women come everyday dressed in street walker casual attire. Of course management doesn't fall behind in their lack of professionalism, instead of focusing on the present task they're more focused on covering themselves and throwing the employees under the bus. . As far as upper management or should I say "Crack Dealers in Suits", sadly I make this comparison because they bring the street and poor upbringing to the job. These so called professionals have been slowly destroying the morale. The company is a three ring circus of cloak and dagger. Management is slithery, secretive, and vindictive with a twist of favoritism . This the most unsavory environment I have ever worked in, if I could give this company no stars I would.

job_title: Marketplace Facilitator Enroller in Bronx, NY
pros:
Metroplus is a stable company with excellent growing opportunities for all employees in all departments.
I have been with this company for six years now and it’s been a great experience thanks to the positive leadership from my supervisor/ management. Yes we have to meet our daily goal but it’s doable if you have the desire and commitment
The part that I enjoy the most about my job is that I'm able to help individuals and families to receive a much needed health insurance so they can receive the best Health Care they Deserve.
Great benefits :  health care for employees / union benefits / 401K / NYCERS ...
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Retention Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Opportunities to all who are passionate and willing to work. Great health plans benefits. Great co- workers each department is more than  willing to teach you about their role.
cons: No room for growth. No incentive, all departments have goals and should have incentives.  Managers need to have a class from external point of view and be thought on Morals, language and be knowledgeable on the department needs and employees frequently asked questions and needs..

review_title: My Opinions about Metroplus Health Plan
job_title: MFE in Bronx, NY
pros: Free Medical for myself and my child,  City job so I get City benefits
cons: Pay is not as competitive as other plans.

review_title: Hmmm beware... FYI the CEO is Arnold Saperstein NOT Bernard Rosen
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: City job & decent benefits. The organization is undergoing major restructuring. New CMO (soon to be CEO) is turning things topsy turvey.  Firing whole departments and 'non performers' to hire her friends from other plans to do the job.
cons: Low pay if you aren't friends with the higher ups or if you are not from the same cultural background as the CEO/new CMO.

job_title: Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Members and coworkers.Benefits are good
cons: New CMO and some management staff .CM dept completely disseminated .Job descriptions and qualifications changed .Entire dept of RNs let go.Staff initially told by HR to apply to other depts which some people did.Applications are ignored and they are hiring from outside.Lies and no respect for  employees although some employees do get unfair special treatment from management .Its who you know and who they like.Definitely no job security  since new CMO hired and oh almost forgot ,we waited 6 yrs for. a raise.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Wall Street, MO
pros: This is a City of New York position and as such, offers a good pension plan and a good choice of health care plans, some of which are free.
cons: Unfortunately, under new management, this has become a challenging environment for Nurses, who,  most of us feel, are not respected.  Yet we are the ones who have the greatest responsibility for the bottom line and customer satisfaction.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: I've been employed with Metro Plus for 15 years.  I can say that I have grown in this company and had several promotions since my start here.  Metro Plus has demonstrated that I am valued as an employee.   Metro Plus has a very diverse population.  I interact daily with staff of all levels.  As an employee, I am treated with respect and my input matters and always considered.
cons: Sometimes, there's a disconnect between other department and ours, where they fail to communicate changes that may affect other areas, other than their own.

job_title: in Woodbridge, NJ
pros: Benefits & holidays. Casual dress Fridays. Relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Too many toxic ideas are allowed to flourish within the company and maintain a strong foothold which sets the company back. There is extreme favoritism when it comes to promotions and a lot shady backdoor deals when it comes to moving people in a position. The departments have almost no communication with each other and like to point the finger at the other department for issues. Micromanagement is a huge problem at the company which doesn't allow departments to properly assess their own issues. Also nepotism is prevalent in the company even though the "rules" state against such practice,  these rules aren't adhered to

review_title: Not bad to start here and expand elsewhere
job_title: Enrollment and Membership Representative in New York, NY
pros: I enjoy my time with Metroplus learned a lot about healthcare and opened my interest in the healthcare management. Consistent schedule with very great benefits. Bring your kid to work and Customer Service yearly acknowledgement event.
cons: Mandatory overtime, long hours at times and work was very repetitive as any call center environment can be.  Staff was very unprofessional and played favoritism. Quota was heavily set on number of calls then quality of service. Mentally draining death with many irate callers .

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: There are good people working together for a common goal, but new management is trying to put her own stamp on the company by disrupting the good that is accomplished
cons: New CMO is a nightmare for staff who have worked hard over the years to serve members.  Dr Schwarts likes to push staff out so she can hire new staff, mainly her friends she work with in her rocky past.  Staff are treated as replaceable cogs in a wheel rather than as human beings with value.

review_title: Run for the hills - if you want to remain sane
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros:
Government job, standard benefits, noble mission to serve the NYC population.
Excellent place to retire. Nice location by Seaport.
cons:
Little to no leadership, leadership is from the bottom up. Systematic abuse of power by executives to encourage nepotism and skim off city funds to award contracts & management positions to friends. 
Substandard salaries for those who are not "favored". Raises are non existent ; unless you are "favored".
Not the place to be if you want to grow your career and develop your skills.

job_title: Marketing Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
Metroplus gave me the opportunity to learn and grow with in the company also to provide excellent service to others,I been so lucky to learn from the best their vision of business and loyalty to their clients and employees is admirable.
Metroplus is always trying to improve and be the best in business
cons: I would not be able to find a reason to dislike Metroplus however , the distance for me is a bit of problem .

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefits (city job)
Good Location
Great work hours.  Once your day is done, you stop everything and leave.
cons:
Poor compensation
Employee apathy
Weak controls
No remote work options (like our competitors)
Management is oblivious
Due to week cybersecurity, their own employees won't use their insurance
And those that do, have had dozens of their co-workers look at their medical claims with little to no oversight.
Let's not talk about the hackers that invade the system daily.
All while the CEO and COO pretend nothing is happening.
Run, don't walk

review_title: Overall, one of the best places I've worked
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Management does not use "Rack & Stack" or "Rank & Yank" to assess employees
- Predicable hours 
- Interesting and challenging projects
-  Real opportunities for job growth & training (not just a tag line)
- Friendly co-workers who are not the "cut throat" wall street type
- One of the last "true" pension plans available
- No "micro-managers"
cons: Tech positions are paid a little under market value.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Genuine compassion from hardworking, excellent co-workers, managers and up - there is an altruistic streak that is rarely seen these days; diverse and stable environment; advancement is certainly possible and encouraged.
cons: Not for everyone; high level strategies can sometimes not make it all the way to the worker level; New York City bureaucracy can be challenging to deal with at times

review_title: Wonderful Case Management Team and staff at large
job_title: Associate in New York, NY
pros: The Case Management Team is exceptional. There is wonderful departmental leadership. The team leads are supportive and professional. There are many well-trained staff with a variety of skills. The training offered is valuable for professional development. This helps you improve the level of support to your colleagues and clients. Overall, people there are very nice and friendly. Solid place for good work life balance.
cons: No further recommendations at this time.

job_title: Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: The biggest Pro is that it is a City job. The pension and retirement benefits are great when someone retires.
cons: The culture is very complex and needs immediate work so the company can succeed in becoming one of the best healthcare companies in NYC.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I worked there for about 8 years. My sales role afforded me the opportunity to network. The pay was also decent.
cons: I understand it's a quota and numbers world but management is always on your neck. I had a supervisor that was unappreciative and would lie a lot to higher ups.

job_title: Enrollment Representative in New York, NY
pros: while I worked at Metroplus, I learned to do so many things that were not in my job description.  The Supervisors value your opinions and do not micromanage.
cons: There was a lot of cattiness and gossiping.

job_title: Intern in New York, NY
pros: As an intern I started at MetroPlus with no experience and not sure if I would enjoy the Healthcare field. MetroPlus is a very welcoming company that helped me learn everyday and were patient when I asked a million questions. Working here made going to work everyday not too bad.
cons: The company could be a little more organized when it comes to more than one department collaborating on an issue

review_title: A good company for Motivated people
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Diverse workforce with some very talented managers and staff. A great place to learn if you are energetic and passionate. A great deal of opportunity for those that work hard and accomplish goals.
cons: Some staff believe this "city job" is a place to coast. They do not last long and there is a bit of turnover.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: MetroPlus is a company that cares about its employees and its customers. The leadership works well together and is always looking out to improve the organization. My supervisor and colleagues are very encouraging and appreciative.
cons: There is sometimes red tape to overcome because of being owned by a city agency

job_title: Retention Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Benefits, Benefits, Benefits...also good experience in the industry
cons: Office Culture is TERRIBLE...it's all about who likes you or who you are related to in order to get a "promotion" in which you have to apply via intranet and hope you get an interview. Promotions are non-existent, don't expect a raise, no bonus or insentive programs and ghetto coworkers.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: The great thing about working for MetroPlus is that it is a city job so if you sign up for NYCERS and work for the city for a minimum of 10 years, you are fully vested for retirement.
cons: There is a lack of promotional opportunities, salaries are low, and most of all, at least 75% of employees at this company are lazy.  There is too much of the "that's not my job" attitude at this company.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: MetroPlus, depending on your department has adopted a very relaxed culture making it easy for a hard working individual to move up the ranks. The pay and benefits are pretty decent.
cons: The caliber of individuals hired at the plan make it hard to truly excel as most are lazy and have a mindset of me against you; losing sight of the team player attitude an environment like this requires.

review_title: We do AMAZING work for NYC
job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: This job gives me the opportunity to do incredibly fulfilling work.  It is the most diverse workplace that I've ever seen.  The benefits and the work life balance are best in class.   We are an integral part of the NYC Public Health System - which is the largest public health system in the country.
cons: At times, the bureaucracy can be a little challenging.

job_title: MIS in New York, NY
pros: Benefits since its under New York City
cons:
1.Micromanagement , mismanagement , miscommunication inter- department and intra-department
2. No chance of growth no matter how hard and diligent you work , unless you are C level favorite.
3.No work urgency no matter how important task is or deadline is approaching.
4. Dirty politics played by C level instead of working on company mission and growth, focus on micromanagement who is sitting on their desk, monitoring there system etc.
5. Lot of rumors, false complain to HR, helpless Labor department, dominated by black and latino's.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Sensitive to employee and member fears and needs during Corona virus crisis.
cons: Some staff take advantage of generous time off and other benefits

review_title: Great Place to Be and Grow With
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful company filled super smart and hard working people. Management and fellow employees always willing to help. This is a great place for those who want to learn managed health care business and make a real impact. Company is constantly looking into improving workplace.
cons: Have not found one.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Some good benefits; work-life balance
cons: Where to begin.... Nepotism is the only way to succeed. No strategy from upper management. People are consistently being scapegoated for upper management failures. Just look at the turnover rate,  good people run away like from a fire. Outdated systems, nasty culture, and rude people. Things are done backward. No recognition, only backstabbing.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The people that work here were very nice and helpful with teaching us new things. It was a great experience; being able to understand what it feels like to work in a real work environment will certainly help me in the future. My supervisor really made this job a comfortable and a wonderful time.
cons: Certain departments need to be more organized.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: City benefits but there are better options elsewhere
cons:
I usually don't leave reviews but decided to leave one here to warn others of joining this organization. Many other companies offer to work remotely a few days per week ,better pay, and value their employee's. 

Horrible work environment. Management is very unprofessional and treat employees as if we are worthless. Unprofessional co-workers and a very high turn over.  It is no worth it.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: City Benefits; Learning Opportunities (internal and external); Exposure to a large Network; Leadership Open Door Policy;
cons: Commute by Public Transportation is horrible, no option to work from home.  Some IT applications are too old making systems integration very difficult or impossible

review_title: Good city benefits but management isnt good
job_title: RN Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: 18 to 25 days vacation days depending on years, 12 sick days, 11 paid holidays with 35 hours work week
cons: Nurses do not have union which is unusual for a city agency. Other coordinators and clerks are unioned.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: MetroPlus is a great company to work for. It is a company that is in the midst of organizational change, due to the new restructured competitive environment of the ACA.
cons: Depending on the department, the operational efficacy was not always optimal.

job_title: Associate Manager in New York, NY
pros: Opportunities for growth, a leadership who wants the plan to shine, and most important of all,  staff who care about our members.
cons: No bonuses for high performers.

job_title: Medicare Sales in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits with union and salary if you're one of the lucky few to have a good salary position.
cons: No cohesion between management and staff. Field workers are stressed to make goal.  Pay extremely low for comparative companies.

job_title: Management in New York, NY
pros: You could count on stable decision making with resigning CEO.
cons: Integrity issues: H+H interests overshadow mplus interests. Medicaid abuse reportable to AG approving all claims for H+H with no medical necessity reviews is a huge gamble for Metroplus and the livelihood of 1200 employees. Who is allowing this? California style?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: They offer many Health care benefit plans
cons: HR  didn't look into the harassment  complaint and management ignored it. They have unions not helpful with one year probation. The pay is low. They have you clock in by writing down on a piece of paper what time you got in the office. They run things like its 1940's still on paper. I  couldn't believe it.  They make promises with no change.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Vacation time and sick leave. Most people are generally hardworking and want the best for the member population. Some people have been there for many years.
cons: Traditionally non-competitive salaries compared to the industry standard. Challenging to bring new ideas to fruition and receive support from management. Limited funding for some initiatives.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: It's a city job so you have great benefits
cons: Nobody is on the same page. You ask the same question to 5 people and you will get 5 different answers. Some managers are also very petty and two faced.

job_title: Marketing Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Health insurance and paid holidays. That's all I can say
cons: Pay union are horrible DC37 Nina Perez  is useless. Union is in bed with management.

review_title: Shuffling the Deck chairs on the Titanic
job_title: Programmer in Newark, NJ
pros:
7hrs per day workday
Not really much positive to say about the company
Get twelve holidays off per year
cons:
Most employees don't care or want to worry about doing things correctly
Management doesn't really have a grasp of what is going on.
Management doesn't encourage working together, and you have multiple people doing the same thing

review_title: MetroPlus is being a part of HHC is a poorly managed organization.
job_title: Senior MIS Analyst in New York, NY
pros: This place has city benefits. This is the place to be if the retirement is your goal. You can show up at work and do nothing all day long. The best place for lazy people. Come join MetroPlus!
cons: There is no real reason for this company to exist. It's a big surprise this place is still in existence.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: MetroPlus Health Plan provided me with opportunities for professional growth.    I love the cultural diversity.
cons: In general, I am satisfied with being a MetroPlus employee.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in New York, NY
pros: During these pressing times, MetroPlus has been so accommodating! My department has offered flexible hours, work from home, and socially conscience.
cons: Work-life balance is a little off, but I don't think that it's at the fault of the company.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in New York, NY
pros: Easy schedule, decent pay, easily accessible
cons: Management is almost nonexistent when needed, chain of command missing, extremely rude customers, no communication,

job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Predictable hours / Nice People / Good Benefits / Lots of Training Opportunities

job_title: in New York, NY

review_title: A lot of room for improvement
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Fulfilling 10 years can earn you a lifetime health insurance which is always a plus since we are city employees.

job_title: Claims Examiner in New York, NY

cons: Promotions are limited. Promote from within

job_title: Outreach Specialist in New York, NY

review_title: Poor benefits, bad management, lazy coworkers

cons: Terrible management who don't care about the people we work for, awful health care benefits, limited PTO, no work from home even though all work was telephonic based, extremely lazy coworkers, no recognition for good work, expected to work late/weekends during audits with no benefits

review_title: Company that cares  for the well being of their employees
job_title: Operations Manager in New York, NY

review_title: It was a rewarding experience working at MetroPlus.
